byline.contributor: Michael Wines reported from Jersey City, and Patrick McGeehan and John Schwartz from New York. Kate Taylor contributed reporting from New York, and Tyler Alicea from Ithaca, N.Y. Alain Delaquérière and Doris Burke contributed research.
byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES, PATRICK McGEEHAN and JOHN SCHWARTZ

abstract: Water contamination crisis in Flint, Mich, has drawn new attention to longtime problem of elevated lead levels in school water supplies throughout United States; issue has been allowed to fester for years due to aged buildings and plumbing, official neglect, tight budgets and gaping loophole in federal rules that largely exempts schools from responsibility for purity of their drinking water.
lead_paragraph: The Flint, Mich., crisis has cast attention on the issue, but in schools from Jersey City, N.J., to Los Angeles, problems have dragged on for years.

headline.main: Schools Nationwide Still Grapple With Lead in Water
headline.print_headline: Lead in Water Still Torments Many Schools

snippet: The Flint, Mich., crisis has cast attention on the issue, but in schools from Jersey City, N.J., to Los Angeles, problems have dragged on for years.
